description.text:
Updated the latch a bit but haven't test printed it yet. If someone prints this then please let me know if the latch works. Thanks!

I needed something to carry my 3D mouse without it getting shaken around too much so I made this thing.

The idea is that it sits compressed in the case with the joystick suspended upside-down so that it doesn't get messed up.

The latch isn't the best, but it works well enough for me. I used 2.85mm filament as a pin for the hinge. Remember to print the latch on its side for strength.

I just uploaded a new rev on the base so hopefully it fixed the issue with the fit of spacemouse in the corners where there used to be gaps. If someone who prints this could also let me know if that issue is fixed then that would be awesome :)

Notes:

Probably doesn't really need the support structure, but I used "touching buildplate" just to be safe with the overhang on the hinges.

May need a bit of light sanding in parts to get them to fit together (mostly with the latch). I had to jam it pretty hard into the top part and knock it with the backside of a screwdriver a few time to get it fully situated. But that negated the need to the original pin hole so I guess it's fine.

author: Grogo666

description.text:
This tool can be used to loosen that Torx-like cap, which is holding the left crankarm on the bottom bracket spindle (see picture). This is needed to swap/clean your crankset or replace the chainrings.
The video here explains how to remove your crankset
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hs_ywOIYzdY
There are plenty of instructions about this procedure online. Don't be worried about this tool being made out of plastic - the original is as well.

1) Print the part.
2) While it is printing you can already loosen the hex nuts of the crankarm.
3) Use the tool to unscrew the cap.
4) You can now remove and clean/swap the crankarms.
Beware that the hex nuts should be fastened with a torque wrench, so (depending on how seriously you take that advice) you're going to need one in order to get everything back together.

description.text:
This is a light painting tool created to give a cloud like light effect. While it did not quite create the effect it was intended it did create quite an amazing effect. Using this in long exposures to light paint creates nicely textured light trails like in the example photo.

There are two designs, one uses only one push button and is meant to be used with regular one colored LEDs the other uses three tactile push buttons to be used with RGB LEDs to control each channel of the LEDs individually.

You will need:

  • 12 x 5mm LEDs
  • 9V battery
  • either one button or three tactile push buttons (check photo for type of button)
  • some wires

The battery is places inside the grip and the LEDs are wired with proper resistors to be switched on/off by the button. The wiring photos show the model that uses three buttons to control RGB LEDs.
You can increase the brightness by gluing tin foil or anything reflective in the case between the LEDs and the diffuser.
This is meant to clip together and glued to keep the diffuser in place. I did not create some mechanism to close the battery chamber because the battery has a tight fit and a bit of black tape can hold the battery lid in place. If anyone wants to design a proper battery chamber you are welcome to do so!

Update 25-11-2016

Updated files. Made the battery chamber a little bit bigger since battery was a real tight fit.
Corrected top case for RGB version, mounting hole of button clamp was on wrong end.
Please download updated files if you want to print RGB version!

print_settings.Notes:: Don't bother with supports, the holes are so small its actually better without supports which can make the edges look messy when removed.

title: MT3608 Micro USB DC-DC boost case

description.text:
This is a case for the 2A Micro USB boost converters found all over AliExpress. The chip used is an MT3608 but the chip is marked as "B6286 (K)"

I use mine to test my 12v projects from a 5v USB powerbank instead of firing up the bench supply. As they can go up to 28v I thought I'd make a case for it.

There's a hole on the side for screwdriver access to the potentiometer. You could perhaps make the case 1-2mm narrower and have the pot sticking out the side.

Round corners for nice printing and press-on lid that requires no glue.

Notes:

I've printed using FlashPrint in PLA with 0.30mm/15% infill and also 0.18mm/100% infill for more rigidity and it looks smoother.

Don't bother with supports, the holes are so small its actually better without supports which can make the edges look messy when removed.

title: Creatbot Dx Plus E3d V5 bowden hot ends

description.text:
Conversion of a Creatbot DX to e3d v5 hotends.

This worked really well, buy the E3d V5 hotends with bowden tube threads. The threads in the E3D head are not quite the same pitch as the creatbot screw adjusters but they are close enough. If I was doing it again I might try V6s and cut threads to fit the creatbot screw adjusters.

You will need to file the fins on the hotends slightly to make sure they fit side by side. I also drilled a small slot for the original creatbot thermistor in the heater block as the E3d ones are not compatible.

You do lose a small amount of Z travel

I have also replaced the bowden tube with an imperial one from E3d that has better tolerance than the creatbot 4mm tube. The tube now extends through the red block all the way to the hotend directly from extruders. You need to drill out the bowden coupling to do this but leaving the retaining spring.

The last mod was to put on some bond tech extruders, makes it quite reliable.

author: MAX_3D_Printer

description.text:
OpenForge bases now support the OpenLOCK system. You can now use any OpenForge 2.0 internal 1x1, 2x1, 2x2, 2x4 and 4x4 tiles with the OpenLOCK system. We've been in discussions with Printable Scenery and we heartily support this open standard for locking tiles.

These Cut-Stone bases are also magnetic. If you want openlock Cut Stone bases without the magnetic holes, we have those as well. For bases with a side that is 1x, we have to choose between openlock and magnets. The files listed as "magnetic_priority" choose magnets, the others choose openlock.

It's worth noting that OpenForge is done on a 50 mm basis, and OpenLOCK on an inch basis. The difference on a 2x2 tile is only 0.8 mm. These bases are on the inch basis, but standard openforge tiles work just fine on them. The size difference is about the same as you can get from standard printing errors, so it's entirely unnoticeable if you use the metric tiles on top of the imperial bases. That being said, if you find the difference bothers you, you can print scale your x and y by 1.016 and you are on the inch scale for the tile too.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

Instructions

There are five factors to consider when selecting a base.

1) The tile size. This will match between the tile and the base, such as 2x2 or 4x2.

2) The tile shape

  • square
  • diagonal
  • curved

3) The base style

  • plain
  • stone
  • ruined

2) What size basis do you want the tiles to be in. There are three choices:

  • 25mm - every square is 25mm on a side. This is compatible with Dwarven Forge. There is no need to scale the tile top with 25mm.
  • inch - every square is 1 inch (25.4 mm). This is compatible with Printable Scenery (OpenLOCK), DragonLOCK and HirstArts. Scale the tile top when you print it by 101.6% in the X and Y axes.
  • wyloch - every square is an inch and a quarter (31.75mm). This is compatible with hero's horde and wyloch tiles. Scale the tile top when you print it by 127% in the X and Y axes.

3) What connection system do you want to use. We offer 4 connectivity options:

  • Magnetic - uses 5mm spherical magnets. 1 each along the center of every square that is on the edge of the tile
  • Magnetic + OpenLOCK - uses 5mm spherical magnets. 1 each along the center of every square that is on the edge of the tile. Also has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square.
  • OpenLOCK - Has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square.
  • OpenLOCK Triplex - Has an OpenLOCK connector at the vertice between each square, and at the center of each square.
  • 02/02/18 - Diagonals had a bug in their names. The size ended with x4 regardless of the actual size.
  • 10/24/17 - Moved to a new version of the scad file, and uploaded new versions of all bases. Also added 25mm/inch/wyloch versions, and curved and diagonal versions.
  • 4/26/17 - Updated scad to let you turn off openlock
  • 12/31/16 - Added missing bases from OpenLOCK 4.0 (EA, SA, SB)
  • 12/31/16 - Added new OpenLOCK clips
  • 12/31/16 - Updated naming convention to match OpenLOCK

It's worth noting that OpenForge is done on a 50 mm basis, and OpenLOCK on an inch basis. The difference on a 2x2 tile is only 0.8 mm. These bases are on the inch basis, but standard openforge tiles work just fine on them. The size difference is about the same as you can get from standard printing errors, so it's entirely unnoticeable if you use the metric tiles on top of the imperial bases. That being said, if you find the difference bothers you, you can print scale your x and y by 1.016 and you are on the inch scale for the tile too.

title: Walkera Runner 250 Racing Drone Full Replacement Shell
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you have an old broken and dusty Walkera Runner 250 sitting in a closet somewhere bring it back to life with style! This is a full frame for the Runner 250 using all the original components. There are two versions of the top plate, one that has a built in GoPro holder and one that does not. The battery compartment has a built in balance plug holder so your balance plug doesn't go flopping around while you are flying. It has a 5 point landing feet for more stable landings. I used various M3 screws, 6mm, 8mm, and 10mm with the corresponding nuts. It flies just like the original, see my short first test flight from the link below. It feels pretty solid also. Best part about this Runner is that you don't have to buy frame parts from Walkera when you break it!
Enjoy!!!
Also, check out my V2 frame which is much lighter than this frame and looks much better.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2012433

Steps for Instillation
  1. Put the 4 nuts in the provided space for the battery box and glue in the nuts on the sides of the frame for the arms.
  2. Screw the battery box to the frame.
  3. Screw in the camera to the front.
  4. Connect the ESC's to the power board using the long oval parts printed from the esc holder file. If you have the OSD unit connect this also.
  5. Use the washers you printed from the ESC holder file to screw the rear lights to the power board. Connect the camera to the power board and carefully slide the power board into place in the frame. The lights cam make it a little bit of a challenge.
  6. Use the washers you printed from the esc holder file to screw the lights to the power board and to screw down the power board to the frame.
  7. Insert two nuts into each of the arms by just popping them in the provided space.
  8. Attach one arm at a time by sliding it into place while popping the ESC plastic pins into place. Put one of the M3-8 or 10mm screws through the arm to screw into the nut you glued in place on the frame. Then use the original ESC screw to screw the ESC to the arm. Repeat this for all four arms.
  9. Attach all four motors using M3-8mm screws.
  10. Connect your VTX, flight controller, and receiver to the power board.
  11. Put the antenna wires through the rectangle slot on the top plate. Use M3-8mm screws to secure the top plate.
  12. Take off your old antenna tubes from the original Runner and cut off the bottom clippy parts. Then string your antennas through it and glue it onto the top of the top plate.
  13. Glue the light covers onto the front and back of the frame.
  14. Go fly and have fun!

author: Iceytee

description.text: I have made the first ever ghost type pokemon, Gastly. Gastly's evolutionary line is arguably the best ghost type line in all of Pokemon so naturally who wouldn't want one? The point of creating Gastly is to train him to his full potential and defeat the elite 4 with only this Gastly. That and he'll most likely be for decoration.

• I began by making the body, I cut the sphere in half so that it would print easier and i would be able to make the insert for the gas. The back was just a semi circle. The front started out as a semi circle but I extruded 2 little hexagons for where the eye's would go, Next I extruded what would be the mouth

  • For the eyes I made semi circles attached to small hexagonal pegs that would fit into the holes I made in the front half of Gastly's body, after I made one I mirrored it to make the opposite eye

  • For the mouth I took the extrusion sketch from inventor and put it in illustrator so that I can change the size seeing as that the ABS plastic shrinks a little bit when printed

  • For the gas I went into illustrator and made a sphere the same size and made the inserts for the gas then free handed the gas

  • After printing everything I used acrylic glue to put it all together

  • the machines I used were the thing-omatic, Replicator 2 and the Epilog Laser Mini

comments.text: Could you make the gas and the mouth pieces stl files please?

comments.text: There is no need to twist your beard. I use a self made ring for my beard and the trick is to put the beard in a piece of transparend sheet (that  kind to protect a sheet of paper) and roll it around the beard. It is easy to understand if you take a look at someone who is making a self rolled cigarette. You can even do it with a sheet of paper it is only important that it is as long as your beard. I would use the transparend sheet or anything that is slash resistant and if rolled will allow you to push the ring over the beard more easily.

author: TikiLuke

title: 608, 625, & 607 bearing Concave Surface Fidget Spinner Buttons MK3.1 (Press Fit)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE Another member pointed out that my models weren't perfectly on the bed in the design, which most decent slicer programs would point out to you and/or automatically correct. So I put them on the bed and re-uploaded everything.

UPDATE
If you find these fidget spinner buttons well designed and useful, please leave a $1 tip to encourage me to create more. I'm happy to redesign these for any bearing size. I also have a project in the works to create a Fidget Spinner Customizer. So you can put in the size of your bearings and a few other details and it will create a 3-5 arm fidget spinner automagically.

UPDATE
I noticed a problem with the sizing of the female portion of the 607 bearings. So I've adjusted it. They are now at mk1.2. (Previously at mk1.1).

UPDATE
I've added 607 Bearing Fidget spinner buttons (caps) to the mix. They are at mk1 and are currently untested until my 607 bearings arrive. But I based them off of my 625 bearing fidget spinner buttons so I have great confidence in them working fine.

UPDATE
I've updated the 625 bearing fidget spinner buttons to mk3.1, I had to add a small ring to keep the buttons from interfering with the spinning of the bearing.

UPDATE
I increased the tolerance on the press fit so that they will now press together easier, and possibly come back apart again without breaking. I also added a medium size to the 608 series, and made several adjustments to the 625 series. All FS Buttons are now at mk3.

UPDATE
I increased the concavity on all the buttons so everything is now at the mark 2 or mark 2.1 version.

UPDATE
Due to the apparent popularity of my fidget spinner buttons, I was inspired to redesign these with a higher face count so the MK2's are now smoother and have bevels. I also added standard sized Spinner Buttons and labeled them both for the 608 bearing. I also included 625 bearing fidget spinner buttons.

I've been obsessing about fidget spinners lately. I've made more than 20. I like the buttons for them to snap together and have a concave surface. It's a tactile thing. While there are other fidget spinner buttons here that meet both of those requirements. They are all too big and cover over the really nice ceramic bearnings that I got. So I designed these from scratch to be concave, snap together, and not hide the workings of the bearings.

I print these out on the Zortrax that we have in the shop. It gives great detail and need almost no finishing on the pieces. I print these in ABS, PLA isn't sturdy enough to print
Fidget Spinners that will last. I recommend you use at least ABS or a higher grade plastic to print all your Fidget Spinner buttons and accessories.

comments.text: Do you have some sort of insert to use a 625 bearing to a 608 spinner?
comments.author: madyicstik

comments.text: No...  I don't sorry.  But I could design one for a fee?
comments.author: madyicstik

comments.text: tried to print the 608 versions of these and for reasons I don't understand just get a scrambled mess on the bed.. maybe i need supports? prusa original mk2s simplify3d. switched to a different button without the concavity and perfect print so it's not a printer or adhesion issue.. looks like it's just printing in mid air.. I get a birds nest of round unsquished filament extruded.. bizarre.. i'l try again with supports.
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: Hello!  Thank you for your comments!
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: You're right, it can't be printed even if rotated 180 degrees.  In S3D, after clicking "Prepare to Print!" grab the end slider and drag it from 0 to the right.  You'll see where the printer is trying to air print.  The 608 caps can't be printed without support.
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: tried again with support and still won't print.. then zoomed in close and looked.. it's a fault in the files.. the small looks OK but the medium and large versions the female doesn't touch the bed.. I'll download and try them as individual files not sets
comments.author: Radish

comments.text: I just checked my models and you were correct they were all just a little bit off of the design build plate.  This is really an issue with the slicing program that you are using.  A good slicing program will tell you the model is off the build plate and automatically correct the issue.  I've re-aligned all the models to be on the build plate, and re-uploaded everything (and incremented the mk to mk3.1).
comments.author: gizmatron

comments.text: Again I suspect your issue is with your slicer program.  I use Cura for printing everything on any of our other 3d printers.  However as I said previously I have only been printing these with z-suite on a zortrax out of z-abs.  I haven't ever tried these on any of our other 3d printers, mostly because the resolution isn't good enough for parts this small.

title: Geiger Counter Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A complete Geiger counter case to hold the Geiger counter electronics, power supply, and tube using the kit from https://sites.google.com/site/diygeigercounter/. The kit consists of the base, lid, and protective covering for a VA-Z 115 tube, along with a snap-in tube holder for the tube on the lid. This design was inspired after seeing the other projects on DIYGeigerCounter's site, and the case design of Stephen. The design goals for my design were to make the entire assembly more compact, add tone and brightness side controls, and allow for the lid to be pressure-fit (removing the need for screws and making the internals easier to access).

The attached python file runs a BRL-CAD script to create the solid model. This script NEEDS TO BE UPDATED so that the executable path points to your installation of BRL-CAD. Then, any of the several BRL-CAD exporters can be used to quickly and accurately export the model to the desired format (such as the attached STL models). The base and lid will just fit on a Printrbot Jr (v1).

title: 18mm auto level sensor support for Anet A8 right side

description.text:
A stiff and stable sensor supoort for the Aner A8 and a LJ18A3-8-Z/BX or any other 18mm diameter sensor.

It is located on the right side to enable better acess to the extruder and placed so that a colision with the heat bed cable is avoided. The disadvantage is that it is located further away from the sensor than those located at the fan.

For autolevel instructions see:
https://3dprint.wiki/reprap/anet/a8/improvement/autobedleveling

Extended fan duct:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2168430
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2037771

My Marlin RC8 setting (should work for Skynet also)

// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)
#define X_MIN_POS -33
#define Y_MIN_POS -10
#define Z_MIN_POS 0
#define X_MAX_POS 220
#define Y_MAX_POS 215
#define Z_MAX_POS 240

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).
#define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 35
#define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
#define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 170
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 65 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -36 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -2.90 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

This is a compact extruder carriage designed for a sunhokey prusa i3 2015, but it probably fits other prusa i3 too.

The cooling fan is mounted on the back of the carriage. But the most unique thing about this design is that the extruder is clamped down at the bottom, fastening the extruder at two points.

It is made in openscad, but its very computer intensive and changing any of the parameters will likely break the design in non obvious ways, so i decided not to add it in the customizer.

This is a BLTouch holder that I've designed to be used on my CL260 UM clone, but I think suitable for any 3d printer,
It has a guide for tune the height using the small tuning cube with a hole in the center.

The cube is 8.2 mm tall.
About the holder mounting and tune cube usage give a look at the pictures.

Printed in ABS, 50%infill, 0,2mm layer.

Printer:

CL260

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Marlin Firmware for CL260

The most important parameters to take into account are:

// Mechanical endstop with COM to ground and NC to Signal uses "false" here (most common setup).
const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool Z_MIN_PROBE_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.

define Z_MIN_PROBE_USES_Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_PIN

define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_FEATURE // Delete the comment to enable (remove // at the start of the line)
define Z_MIN_PROBE_REPEATABILITY_TEST // If not commented out, Z Probe Repeatability test will be included if Auto Bed Leveling is Enabled.

define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 5
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 215

Here I use a 3 x 3 grid
define AUTO_BED_LEVELING_GRID_POINTS 3

and finally:
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -23 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 20 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -1.0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]

// Useful to retract a deployable Z probe.
define Z_PROBE_END_SCRIPT "M280 P0 S90"

Pay attention to the Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER because you should measure this value (-1.0 in my case) after having levelled the bed with the command G29.

Moreover consider that the Z min endstop will not function as usual, so don't home the Z axis (so comment any reference to the Z homing in your start print gcode).

Usually, after the calibration) I do like this:
G28 X0 Y0
G29
G1 Z0 for homing the Z axis.

Firmware repository

I've pulled on bitbuket the customized Marlin firmware (V1.1.0. RC6) for CL260 + BLTouch + Full Graphic LCD.

https://bitbucket.org/effebal/cl260-bltouch-version-marlin-1.1.0-rc6

Note: if you want to use this fw with the orignal LCD you need to modify the lcd section in the configuration.h file.

comments.text: Make a mention in the comments to check that Marlin is configured to the correct lcd - that is where I messed up!

title: Filament Reel-To-Printer Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This simple guide was designed to help prevent filament from unwrapping from brand new reels (for printers that mount the reels against their side/back). The reason the brand new reels were unwrapping was because the filament is pulled from the edges of the reel and filament retractions would cause the filament on the reel to escape the barely exposed sides of the reel. This part holds the filament guide tube and angles it away from the surface on which it is mounted (by glue or two-sided tape), allowing the filament to be pulled from the center of the reel rather than the edge. Its dimensions fit the guide tubes for 1.75 mm diameter filament reels but should be easy to scale up for larger diameter filaments.

title: X Belt tensioner for Malyan M150

description.text:
I looked at some solutions for wanhao and similar i3 clones like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1672640 and the remixes but they all don't really fit Malyan M150 properly as M150 comes with 3 linear bearing blocks that are different in size from Wanhao (and especially different from those upgrades ppl put on Wanhao) hence all the files I tried didn't really work. I tried editing them but it's tedious work to edit STL (why don't ppl upload source files still is beyond me) so I reworked it from scratch .. so it is similar to /thing:1672640 but it properly fits Malyan M150. It also works perfectly in conjunction with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1906153 :)

NOTE: DO NOT OVER-TIGHTEN YOUR X BELT! When you plan to change the X belt tension do that when the X assembly is at the bottom or at the top of the printer, do not tighten too much as you can easily bend the Z guide rods! Especially if you are increasing tension while X assembly is at the middle of the Z!!

UPDATE: changed geometry, used better dimensions, the thing:1672640 I was using at starting point assumes poorly calibrated printer so everything is "sloppy" and loose :( ..

UPDATE 201611231820: new image of v1.1 fitted, works flawlessly :D

UPDATE 201611250215: added "x-belt tensioner for M150 - linear" if you don't like loop you can use this one to attach your belt to the fixed side with teeth grove like it is on the variable size

Printer:

self made

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

there's a thin wall 0.4mm on the object. Print using 0.4mm "line" or configure your slicer to detect thin walls, anyhow even if that thin wall is not printed at all (as if you don't detect thin wall and your slicer is configured to print with larger line then 0.4mm it will be ignored) the part is still 100% functional!

main tensioner block is properly rotated for printing, sliding block you have to rotate 180 degrees (around x or y) so that screw head hole prints properly.

onshape

onshape source of the whole project available:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7cb155e953d26af39c1b9508/w/cac13f9b8a666666c8f0e621/e/8dbd92b8547ecb7d5ffd2531

comments.text:
Why don't you attach the belt on the fixed side the same way as on the adjustable ? More elegant than a loop. I always attach my belts with a tooth profile on carriage. Takes less space so things can be made smaller.
BTW, looks like the belt tooth side may rub on the top. It is why it would be better to reverse the way it is mount ed.

Diese erste Version meines Lego_Brick enthaelt alle Standard laengen und breiten der original Lego-Bricks.
Es lassen sich laenge breite hoehe und mit/ohne Noppen angeben und schon erzeugt Openscad den Stein. Dieses Projekt ist enstanden weil ich mit OpenScad lernen wollte und weil ich frueher ein passionierter Legobauer war und vielleicht wieder werde. Viel Spass Damit Update 29.11.13:
Die Legoeinheiten wurden in eine Seperate Scad Datei gelegt. Die anderen Dateien wurden dementsprechend angepasst und eine erste Vorabversion für Technic Steine wurde ergänzt.

use   
KLOTZ(2, 2, 3, Tile=false); //X_Noppen, Y_Noppen, Hoehe in Legolayer (*3,2), glatte Fliese=nein/ja)  
Das Inlay passt sich den original Laengen an.  
Es empfiehlt sich X<=Y anzugeben.

description.text:
"Once a powerful stage magician's rabbit, Mr. Puffs now walks the surfaces of Hell in a demonic form. His previous insatiable appetite for carrots has been replaced for an eternal hunger for human souls."

This character was designed for IGG contributor Jonathon Sullivan (and creator of his own gaming company, Weird Labs) and was based on a character design for his in-development tabletop game, Guardians & Goons (based on the reference art shown). If you want to print a 28mm scale version of this model, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

author: Rockman2000

title: FL Sun Delta Power Supply Cover

description.text:
I have a son who is into my 3D printers, so i don't like having live wires exposed.

This is my case for my FL Sun Delta Power Supply. It uses a switched, fused IEC socket as per http://www.maplin.co.uk/p/10a-fused-snap-in-iec-chassis-plug-with-switch-n94cz.

This will sit portrait against your printer, it has an extrusion to sit in the aluminium frame and 2 holes that can be screwed into the frame to lock it in place. There is an exit hole for the controller board power on the back that comes out between the 2 extrusions.

The pic is of the 1st design which had the missing hole for the controller board power and the vent holes were too low, stl has been updated with these changes. Also i did not realise how much filament was left that is why there is a colour change!

Might be worth checking the dimensions of your power supply before attempting this as they may be different.

author: Reisingera03

title: Titan Extruder mount for Lulzbot Taz 6 with E3D V6 Hotend

description.text:
WARNING! This upgrade is for EXPERTS!
E3d Titan Extruder Mount for Lulzbot Taz 6. This replaces the stock extruder with an E3D Titan and V6 Hotend.
Requires:
E3D Titan Extruder
24v E3D V6 Hotend
38mm or shorter (pancake is ok) stepper motor. Stock Stepper is too long!
8x M3 Heat Inserts
2x M2 Heat Inserts
2x M2 8mm screws
4x M3 12mm Countersunk (flat socket head cap) screws
1x 30mm 5v fan
2x 40mm 24v fan
1x Microswitch (Digikey Part: SW768-ND)
1x 16 pin Connector Housing (Digikey PN: WM2525-ND)
20x Male Crimp Connectors (Digikey PN: WM2517-ND)
Misc M3 screws for fan mounting.
Printed Parts

Assembly

Follow wiring guide here: https://ohai.lulzbot.com/project/taz-6-extruder-assembly/taz-6/

I recommend you assemble everything before cutting and crimping wires. Double check pin1 orientation. make sure you put the pins in the right location.

Be ready to shutoff the machine if anything goes wrong. The X axis might be off a bit, I have not been able to verify the correct location, so WATCH your machine, make sure the nozzle hits the correct locations on the auto-level washers. Make sure it hits the Z endstop button. be prepared to shutoff the machine if it is misaligned!

title: Star Trek TNG Combadge (Communictaor)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a two-piece model of a combadge from Star Trek: The Next Generation. I used measurements taken from an official, licensed metal-cast combadge by QMX, who claims they used the original molds from the show props.

I called the pieces "vector" (the silver part) and "pedestal" (the gold part).

The tolerances are so tight that you can snap the vector into the pedestal and probably never have to worry about it coming out, or you add a dab of glue to be sure.

If you don't like the layered look (a la the second photograph), you can print the vector on its edge (but you'll have to use support). It really gives the front of it a nice look.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select Plus

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

MAX

Infill:

approaching 100%

Notes:

If you're printing both parts lying flat, you don't need any support, but printing the vector with a raft is really helpful if you tend to have squished first layers.

If you choose to print the vector on it's edge, like <(, then obviously, you will.
I used a pair of calipers to take a lot of measurements from the officially licensed prop piece, and modeled it in Fusion 360.

description.text:
This is a dummy connector for covering the pins on your motherboard's fan headers.

I included STLs for 3-pin and 4-pin versions. The 4-pin version can be used on 3-pin headers but it will hang off the side (as shown in the picture).

EDITED 2016-12-28: Added version 2

I separated the pin pockets to greatly reduce the risk of shorting out the pins. I recommend only using version 2.

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro (2016)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed in ABS, but just about any filament should do so long as it's not conductive and can handle any nearby heat sources without deforming.

You may get a prompt for auto-scaling if you slice the 3-pin version in Simplify 3d. Select "no" - the mesh file is already in millimeter format.

Designed in FreeCad 0.16

The size is determined solely by the padding of the base plate sketch - set padding length to 8mm for the 3-pin version and 10.6mm for the 4-pin version.

Version 2 is the same model fused with primitive cubes to separate the pins. I added these when I realized that the height of the cover makes it easy to bend the pins and cause a short - separating them should help prevent this (regardless, use this object at your own risk).

Remix - repaired the stl files as they were causing issues with my printer. Didn't see a way to attach the head so I put a hole in it to fit the body. Had problems with the arms snapping, so I strengthened them. Added the Sketchup file for further re-mixing goodness.
The parts are very small. I had luck printing them in ABS with a .2mm layer height on my UP! mini. I chose Solid infill as the smaller parts were weak otherwise.

comments.text:
Well smell. I don't skip anymore, but I keep breaking off the "middle petals" during the print.
I tried at 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 mm layers (0.4mm nozzle on Robo3D). If I could convince Slic3r to not do a high-speed move from edge petal to center, I think I'd be golden :/
comments.author: ThorMJ

comments.text: There may be a "travel speed" listed separately from the perimeter, fill, etc. speed settings that you can decrease. Also, lowering or eliminating the retraction between moves may help as well. Worth a shot.
comments.author: ThorMJ

comments.text: Usually that would indicate that your motors are skipping steps. If that is the case, then either the motors don't have enough power and you need to adjust the little trimpots so that they get more amps (don't turn it up too high or else the stepper drivers will overheat and stop until they cool down). Or you're simply trying to go too fast.
